instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Turning On, Liquid Damage
Macbook Pro Retina <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Turning On, Liquid Damage
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.60v
PPBUS S5 HS COMPUTING 12.60v
PPBUS S5 HS OTHER5V 12.60v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER3V3</SIGNAL> 12.60v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S4_X239</SIGNAL> missing 0V
PPVIN S4 TPAD missing 0v
PP3V42 G3H 3.42v 
PPVRTC G3H 3.34v
PP5V S5 5.01v
PP5V S4 missing 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> missing 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> missing 0v

On <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> Pin number 4 <SIGNAL>P5VS3_ENABLE</SIGNAL>  missing, I tried to trace back where it creates, found it on on page 64 after <RESISTOR>R8179</RESISTOR>, that resistor is fine , missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> now I am stuck here to look further 

Please adviced, I attached pictures where it was liquid damage
Already changed <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> but no difference 


Thanks

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Turning On, Liquid Damage
threads.message:
omg never seen anything like this 
If battery is connected macbook turns on and works fine
I plug charger while battery connected works fine, disconnect battery while it is running still works well, restart computer without battery , it will restart fine , it just not turn on without battery, after turns on i can disconnect battery no issues :(

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Turning On, Liquid Damage
threads.message: when I plug Charger it takes about .20amp

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Turning On, Liquid Damage
threads.message: Disregard anything I said before. Does the Mac charge the battery? If so, then make sure you are using a known GOOD 60 or 85 watt OEM magsafe 2 charger. The 2015 Macs I have found are very finicky depending on the charger you use. Sorry for any confusion from before your post on the battery confused me when I first read it.

threads.title: Macbook Pro Retina <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Not Turning On, Liquid Damage
threads.message: Green/orange light present? Using at least a 60W charger? You should only have a REAL 85W charger for testing as all MacBooks will power on from 85W.
